title: You can write in first and third person. Is there a 'second person'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, there is  N.K. Jemesin, author of the Broken Earth trilogy (image sources [1] [2]) In the first book of the trilogy, The Fifth Season, the author uses all three points of view — first, third, and second — as a way to keep three different story-lines separate. There is also a nice twist to that, which I will not spoil. So — yes — it is indeed possible to write from a second person perspective too. It is unusual, and hard to pull off. But possible. Footnotes[1] N. K. Jemisin - Wikipedia[2] https://www.amazon.co.uk/Broken-Earth-Trilogy-Box-set/dp/0356513750/ref=pd_lpo_14_img_0/258-1621689-2086123?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=0356513750&pd_rd_r=a239f92d-b6b7-40ee-8bd1-e9f7407356b2&pd_rd_w=cBDLZ&pd_rd_wg=eVI67&pf_rd_p=7b8e3b03-1439-4489-abd4-4a138cf4eca6&pf_rd_r=VZDV8G8AHSXZ4FKPKCEJ&psc=1&refRID=VZDV8G8AHSXZ4FKPKCEJ

Yes there is a second person. The second-person point of view belongs to the person (or people) being addressed. This is the “you” perspective. Once again, the biggest indicator of the second person is the use of second-person pronouns: you, your, yours, yourself, yourselves. You can wait in here and make yourself at home. Writing in the second person requires use of the pronouns you, your, and yours. This point of view is used to address the audience in technical writing, advertising, songs and speeches.
